stream_context.summary: Kaze prototypes a new Wild-West course, polishes Star names and an intro cut-scene for Oily Boily Bay, and debugs a crash caused by newly added colour-coded warp pipes.

development_findings.summary: Wild-West course will have two sub-areas: a frontier town hub and a canyon ‘set-piece’ zone containing a gigantic shotgun, wheel, skull and hoof-iron the player can platform on.
Four colour-coded warp pipes act as optional shortcuts between distant corners of the canyon; colours must be distinguishable for colour-blind players and stay one-cycle to preserve N64 performance.
development_findings.quote: These pipes are just shortcuts; the worst that happens is you pop back out and lose five seconds.

development_findings.summary: Star #1 of the course is a scavenger-hunt for hidden treasure, guided by signs that chain the player through the set-pieces.
Oily Boily Bay received finalized working titles for all six Stars and an opening camera cut-scene synced to the level music using spline paths.
Kaze insists the ROM remain 64 MB or smaller so it fits a stock N64 cartridge and will ship open-source.
development_findings.quote: I’m not going above 64 megabytes; technically you can, but I’d consider that cheating.

development_findings.summary: Concept floated for a second project: a very easy, friction-free 10-level hack (20 Stars each, no boot-outs) inspired by SpongeBob BFBB and Mario Odyssey, aimed at mass appeal.
Technical bug: adding the warp-pipe object crashed the game; resolved by creating a separate geo-layout that reads pipe colour from bparam2 and by debugging the PC address in NEMU64.
development_findings.quote: The crash is in my code here – geoset_pipe_color – so who needs debug symbols.

development_findings.summary: Fast64 Blender plug-in is used to export models directly to N64 format; pipes now use a single-cycle material with a hand-drawn highlight texture.
Intro cut-scene timing is determined entirely by musical beats; camera cuts are adjusted frame-by-frame to hit drum accents.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s design philosophy: modern games are ‘so bad’ that an inoffensive, frustration-free platformer would be wildly popular.
context_findings.quote: If you make a game that is just not offensive to the player… people will love it.

context_findings.summary: He refuses to monetize the hack to avoid Nintendo legal action and will release it for free.
Strong aversion to the Parallel64 emulator; prefers NEMU64 for debugging and real hardware for accuracy.
context_findings.quote: Parallel-launcher tards can’t just let me not use it in peace.

context_findings.summary: Frustration with PayPal locking his account; considering crypto but dislikes the fees and tax headaches.
Notable mood swings: excitement over viewer spike, irritation when chat pressures him about emulators, playful banter about eating toothpaste and Christmas gifts.

biobak.summary: Responsible for finishing several unfinished areas (power-plant interiors and underground retro zone) and the upcoming Wild-West canyon details.
Payment stalled because PayPal has frozen Kaze’s account; alternate methods being explored.

badub.summary: Composes all current level tracks, including the Wild-West theme used during the stream.
badub.quote: He always makes the music for my levels nowadays.

zeina.summary: Modeling a large canyon skull for the Wild-West set-piece; Kaze reviews and approves the WIP live.
Lighthearted personal presence: provides food (schnitzel) and banter; no direct technical role in this session.

key_stories.title: Pipe Crash and Fix
key_stories.summary: Kaze introduces colour-coded warp pipes, but the game instantly crashes on load. He isolates the problem, discovers the geo-layout was reading an uninitialized value, and rewrites it to fetch colour data from bparam2, confirming the fix in NEMU64.
key_stories.challenge: Game hard-crashes when warp pipe model is added.
key_stories.process: Commented out pipes, traced PC address in NEMU64, rewrote geoset_pipe_color, rebuilt textures, re-tested.
key_stories.outcome: Stable, visually distinct one-cycle pipes now function as intended.
key_stories.key_quote: Who needs debug symbols – the crash is in my code here.

key_stories.title: Cut-scene on the Beat
key_stories.summary: The opening panorama for Oily Boily Bay must land each camera cut on specific drum hits. Kaze iteratively edits spline lengths, shifting cuts by 1–3 frames at a time until visual motion matches the soundtrack.
key_stories.challenge: Initial camera cuts felt off-beat and too quick.
key_stories.process: Playback with music maxed, counted frames between beats, adjusted spline durations, retested repeatedly.
key_stories.outcome: Final three-shot cut-scene now lines up precisely with musical accents.
key_stories.key_quote: The most important part of the cutscene is that it’s fitting to the music.

key_stories.title: PayPal Freeze Hits Art Pipeline
key_stories.summary: Kaze cannot pay Biobak because PayPal locked his account, jeopardising the completion of unfinished areas Biobak owns.
key_stories.challenge: Payment channel to graphics artist is frozen.
key_stories.process: Discusses crypto as workaround but dislikes fees and tax implications.
key_stories.outcome: Issue unresolved; Biobak’s current work status uncertain.
key_stories.key_quote: I want to pay Biobak with paper money but PayPal is not letting me use PayPal right now.

open_questions.topic: Final name for the Wild-West course
open_questions.context: Several placeholders floated (Wild West Valley, Western Wilds, Cowboy Country, High Noon Hills) but none chosen.
